data:
Exclusion Criteria: 
- Patients less than 12 months old
- Previously failed sedation or extreme anxiety
- Raised intracranial pressure
- Severe neurological impairment, severe bulbar dysfunction
- Malignant hyperthermia
- Difficult airway syndromes: abnormal face, mouth, dentition, or neck (eg. micrognathis, Apert’s Goldenhar’s)
- Sleep apnea, stridor, airway obstruction, severe asthma
- Tracheal abnormalities or compression (e.g. mediastinal mass)
- Severe cardiorespiratory disease
Refer to Guidelines: Procedural Sedation: Non-Critical Care Areas
Record blood pressure, heart rate, respiratory rate, temperature
Record q5min during and post sedation until pre-procedure level of consciousness is resumed
q5min. Provider must be present until Arousal Score is 2 or less
q5min. Provider must be present until Arousal Score is 2 or less
Refer to Pre Anesthesia and Procedural Sedation Fasting Guidelines
Simultaneous use of benzodiazepines and opioids will have synergistic effects causing increased risk of sedation and respiratory depression

Caution: 
If patient has received local anaesthetic for venepuncture in the previous 12 hours. Local
anaesthetic cream / gel is usually applied to one site per patientcaine-prilocaine or tetracaine for lumbar puncture or IV insertion
Select lidocaine-prilocaine or tetracaine for lumbar puncture or IV insertion
1 application, topical, once, drug form: cream
1 application, topical, once, drug form: top liq
Select midazolam and or fentanyl or ketamine
Ketamine is recommended for children less than or equal to 9 years
Midazolam with or without fentanyl is recommended for children older than 9 years
1 mg/kg, IV, once, drug form: inj
0.5 mg/kg, IV, once, drug form: inj
0.5 mg/kg, IV, once, drug form: inj
1 mcg/kg, IV, once, drug form: inj
0.1 mg/kg, IV, once, drug form: inj
If rescue medications required, CALL CODE BLUE and begin resuscitation procedures
0.01 mg/kg, IV, once, PRN other (see comment), drug form: inj
0.01 mg/kg, IV, q2min, PRN reverse opioid effect, drug form: inj
0.1 mg/kg, IV, once, PRN other (see comment), drug form: inj
